Award.AwardTitle: Liquid crystalline materials containing boron clusters for electrooptical and cation transport application
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The proposed research is a continuation of the current NSF award supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program and involves design, synthesis, and study of liquid crystalline materials that are uniquely suited to address fundamental questions and applied problems in the field of liquid crystals. The proposed materials are liquid crystals containing boron clusters, a class of compounds that display unusual steric and electronic properties. Because these materials have a potential to meet technological needs in modern society, the project has two related goals: i) the development of new nematic materials for applications in flat panel displays and ii) new smectic liquid crystalline electrolytes for rechargeable Li+ ion batteries. The project involves the molecular design of new materials aided by quantum-mechanical calculations, inorganic/organic synthetic methods, structure-property relationship studies, electrooptical characterization and ion mobility investigations.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This multidisciplinary program supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program is directed towards the development of new advanced molecular materials for addressing fundamental questions in the field of liquid crystals and for applications in flat panel displays and rechargeable batteries. The design involves unique organic-inorganic hybrid molecules, which will be synthesized and investigated using a broad array of modern research tools. The proposed work will affect a number of areas of science and engineering, and is expected to impact display and energy storage technologies. It will provide excellent opportunities for involved personnel (undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral workers) to obtain broad training in modern materials chemistry through research and also domestic and international collaborations, which include LCD industry. The aesthetic appeal of liquid crystals and their significance in modern technologies make them an attractive topic for outreach programs and public presentations, which will be continued during the current funding period.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project sponsored by NSF focuses on understanding of the behavior of rationally designed liquid crystalline materials containing boron clusters – unusual inorganic cage compounds (Figure 1) – in the presence of external stimuli, such as an electric field and light, and the development of new materials for display and battery applications.

In general, liquid crystals are fluids, in which molecules exhibit a certain degree of order and alignment. Consequently, the liquid crystalline state represents a unique combination of properties typical for liquids (e.g. fluidity) with long-range ordering characteristic for solid crystals. Another consequence of the structure and arrangement of molecules is that liquid crystalline phases are anisotropic, that is their optical and dielectric properties depend on the orientation of the molecules. Thus, using an external electric field, molecules possessing a dipole moment can be realigned, causing a change in optical properties. This phenomenon is at the heart of the multi-billion dollar liquid crystal display industry, and is investigated in our group further by using specifically designed compounds. The investigated materials are nematic and smectic liquid crystals and their design takes advantage of the unique steric and electronic properties of boron clusters such as [closo-B10H10]2-, [closo-1-CB9H10]-, [closo-1-CB12H12]- and carboranes (Figure 1).

Research conducted in the context of this NSF-supported project has led to three important discoveries in the area of boron cluster chemistry, which impacted our project and also contributed to the areas of inorganic and materials chemistry. Thus, we have discovered a general method for functionalization of closo-borate clusters, which opened up unprecedented access to a variety of polar and ionic liquid crystals. We also developed access to isomerically pure derivatives of o-carborane, and used them to prepare novel materials designed for LCD applications.

Using these and other methods, we have prepared and fully characterized several series of compounds belonging to 5 classes of boron cluster derivatives. The prepared compounds permitted determination of extensive structure-property relationships and identification of most promising leads in the quest of effective highly polar additives to nematic liquid crystal hosts. Using specifically designed pairs of compounds we answered fundamental questions in liquid crystal science, as to what extend a dipole moment and electric charge stabilize the liquid crystalline phase.

The performed work involved molecular design of new materials aided by quantum-mechanical calculations, inorganic/organic synthesis, structure-property relationship studies, and their structural, thermal, optical, and electrooptical characterization.

This interdisciplinary research program has impacted several areas of science and provided excellent opportunities for interdisciplinary training and intrenational collaborations. Thus, results obtained in this project have been described in 15 peer-reviewed publications and presented at a dozen national and international professional meetings. The obtained results have made contribution to synthetic and structural chemistry of boron clusters, and made an impact on fundamental and applied aspects of liquid crystal research.

The project has affected training of 4 postdoctoral researchers, 4 graduate students, and 5 undergraduates. The impact on personnel training was amplified further by involving the nearby located Middle Tennessee State University, where postdoctoral researchers work jointly with undergraduate students on aspects of the project.

Research conducted in the context of this project involved also international collaborations and visits of students from Japan and Poland to our laboratory. Characterization of some materials (powder XRD and single crystal XRD) was performed in collaboration with colleagues in Europe.

Thus, 13 researchers involved in this project have obtained broad training in the interdisciplinary area of modern materials chemistry (chemical synthesis, characterization, and elements of device engineering) in the spirit of international collaboration.

Finally, research progress was paralleled by outreach activities in the Adventure Science Center in Nashville, where the PI and members of his research group were demonstrating liquid crystals to the general public with hands-on activities.
